results.content:
This course is much better viewed as a speedy run through of Meteor tips and best practices than a code-along-with course.  It's definitely for the experienced Meteor developer, and it will greatly increase your efficiency with Meteor. Following the course, I was able to replicate, in about three hours, an app I'd previously spent several weeks on. And the organization is much better and I have proper routing in the new one.

If you like to code along with the instructor, you can still do that to an extent and with the caveat that you'll spend a great deal of time looking up solutions on Stack Overflow, or going through the downloadable code. The course is fast-paced, and many steps are simply not covered. That's not completely important, depending on what you're looking to get out of it. If you are at the expert level, then I think you'll find it to be more interesting having to spend some time finding things out for yourself. Think of it as homework.

If you start this course and get frustrated after the first few sections, stop coding and just watch. I think you'll be more satisfied with the technique once you do. And since it's only three hours, you should be able to find time to review it frequently, until you become a true Meteor master.

results.content: The example used, product and cart, was simple to understand and with the inclusion of bootstrap made a nice visually appealing application.  The tutorial is packed full of examples and guidance that I am sure I will use in the future building my own Meteor Framework based web applications.  I also really appreciate the deployment section which is something commonly overlooked in other Meteor tutorials.
results.content_html: The example used, product and cart, was simple to understand and with the inclusion of bootstrap made a nice visually appealing application. The tutorial is packed full of examples and guidance that I am sure I will use in the future building my own Meteor Framework based web applications. I also really appreciate the deployment section which is something commonly overlooked in other Meteor tutorials.

results.content:
This is an excellent tutorial of Meteor.
 The author is a good teacher as well, incrementally introducing the student to new concepts with a playful tone and he anticipates the thought patterns and confusion points for beginners

I personally appreciate it when an author tries instead to establish a good flow and introduces ideas dynamically, at the time when each idea can be most appropriately introduced and can be reinforced most effectively by the surrounding content. This author seems to understand this pattern better than most and it makes him a good teacher for it.

What I enjoyed most about this tutorial was the structure of the content, each section begins by trying to get you up and running with Meteor and building a application that has real life use as quickly as possible, and its amazing how simple it is to get to that point!
You go through the necessary high-level discussions of the Meteor framework, the needs it addresses, the history of MVC-like patterns in web development.

The latter half of the tutorial then builds upon the earlier, simple application with more realistic looking UI design, C.R.U.D. operation implementation, authentication, robust configuration of role-based event broadcasting and database access, and finally to deployment. So you can definitely say the content here is covered from basics to basic tour of high-level concepts.

Meteor is a full-stack JS framework and streamlines many high-level patterns and technologies that you'd end up implementing by hand in many other frameworks.

Make sure to go view it twice to the concepts can stick and try to tweak the developed application to your preferences to test the concepts you have.

results.content:
The course is not presented in a coherent fashion. Sections are out of order, and the tutor adds code that has errors, so it doesn't work. He also adds extra code sections that are important, but these aren't in the tutorial at all - you can see that the code has changed in later videos.
Very confusing, difficult and frustrating - we have paid money for this - please fix the problems. It could be a good course.

results.content: I wish there was a basics of programming class that was available before this. However, this class is fantastic. Having a Java background many of the concepts here are pretty simple to grasp. Also, a class to have after this one with design patterns for projects that are not single page apps would be useful.

results.content:
'Mastering Meteor' was a good, comprehensive course on advanced meteor techniques. The production quality was good & the instructor's delivery was clear, crisp, interesting & engaging. I did not get distracted or bored during the course, even though Meteor or the newer javascript stacks aren't my core competency.

Some asides though, as the title suggests, you really should be comfortable with Javascript, & ideally should have dabbled with Meteor  before you begin this course.
For example, the deployment topic (section 8), & covers deployments on Amazon EC2 & the Meteor cloud hosting in greater detail than local deployments. So ideally, you should have covered those topics before beginning this course.

I am deducting 1 star, because the code provided isn't flawless, I wasn't able to replicate the instructors steps without some effort (which I don't mind, I'd have given it 4.5 stars if I was able to)

Edit: I am now able to give .5 stars, so have updated my rating to 4.5.

results.content:
Everything is fine except the rapid speed. (5 stars)

---

I think I should change my review to 3.5 stars.

pros - 
1. This course uses flow router.
2. This course does not waste time in explaining basic skills of meteor, javascript, css, etc.

cons -
1. This course uses Webstorm.
2. Way too fast. This course always forces me to stop, rewind, and play.
3. perhaps the biggest cons, MISSING SNIPPETS. New snippet pops out everywhere. Even if it had never shown before, it appears. It leads my website to not match with that of lecture. 
4. Not that 'expert level' as advertised.

results.content:
This is a very good course, but be forewarned you will do a lot of pausing if you want to actual type the code.  I purchased it because of the use of Flow Router rather than Iron Router.

The instructor uses webstorm as an IDE which has been setup with a lot of hotkeys.  While this is great and what I would do when doing actual development work, it makes it very hard for people following the videos and enter the code by hand (best way to learn).

There are also major disconnects in topics being discussed and what you see on the screen.  There are times thing such as login buttons show up, but they were not mentioned.  These are later in the course.  Guessing the instructor needed a new screenshot and used a later revision.  This again makes it very hard to follow as you are constantly looking to see if you missed something.

While I said the content is good, and I still feel that way, this course is very poor due to the presentation.  If you are going to use it as reference, you should be fine.

DO NOT pay full price for this course.  Wait till you can get it at a discount.

results.content: The author of this work does a good job in explaining Meteor as a platform by touching on all the practical aspects of meteor that a real world app should have. Even at that, the course proceeds at a somewhat manageable pace and can still be completed over a weekend. Its the only  complete course that has a section on testing meteor apps. The choice to use flowRouter for the app is excellent because the Meteor ecosystem is expanding to cover Angular and React as well as Blaze. My only gripe with the course is that it should have explored some more aspects of these other front-end frameworks. However, I still gave it five stars because of testing and the deployment to AWS.
